subject: Harry Smith: When Lightening Strikes
body:

May 17, 
      2007
 

Hi, 
      everybody,
 
Our crazy spring continues in New York. 
      Yesterday, right around 
      suppertime, noisy thunderstorms rolled through the city and the suburbs. 
      There was a dramatic picture of lightening striking above the Empire State 
      Building. And, it brings to mind how dangerous lightening can be. We 
      talked today with meteorologist 
      and lightening safety expert 
      John Jensenius who reminded us that in a average year more people are 
      killed by lightening strikes than hurricanes and tornados. We showed the 
      dramatic video from Texas of two school children who narrowly missed being 
      hit by a bolt of lightening. If you haven't seen it yet, take a look. 
      
 
We had a nice chat with 
      our friend Bob Schieffer about the ongoing dissatisfaction among 
      Republicans with the candidates who are running for the Republican presidential 
      nomination thus far. Bob said he thought former 
      Tennessee Sen. Fred Thompson would 
      eventually enter the race, and maybe 
      Newt Gingrich, too. But the real 
      interesting turn in our talk came when we discussed New York 
      City Mayor Michael Bloomberg. A brand new poll out this 
      week from the New York Daily News shows New Yorkers think 
      Bloomberg is a better mayor than Rudy Giuliani and New Yorkers think 
      Bloomberg would make a better president, too. Bloomberg is worth billions of 
      dollars and has more that enough money to mount a national campaign out of 
      his own pocket. If Bloomberg were to run, it's 
      a pretty good guess that he would run as an Independent. I 
      asked Bob if he thought an Independent could be elected president and he 
      said yes. 
 
Also on the show, Hannah 
      had a nice chat with Antonio Banderas (he's 
      in "Shrek the Third"), Julie got to grill 
      brats and hot dogs with Bobby Flay (I'm seriously jealous) and you'll want to take a look at 
      a segment by our new contributor, 
      Mary Lou Quinlin. She has some really interesting observations that 
      you'll really enjoy. 
 
Tomorrow, Mary Lou 
      will be exploring what women really think about motherhood. Also 
      tomorrow, Mike Myers will be here to talk about his role 
      as "Shrek"; we'll have a behind-the-scenes look at the 
      "CSI: Crime Scene Investigation" season finale tonight; and we'll learn 
      how to protect our kids from online sex offenders.
